header: Add OR conditions to spam rules
idea_text: Add OR conditions to Spam rules. Currently, if you want to prevent spam, you can only add a rule with AND. This makes each condition less effective. If you get a match on one of them and not the rest, the spam gets through. We are getting bombarded with Dropbox phishing scams. They are coming with different TO, FROM, and SUBJECT information. The common factor is that one of those three usually contains the words "dropbox" "sharing" "connect@" or "box". But not always in the same field. And then the exception is the actual domain for dropbox, so that it will come through if valid. Lacking an OR condition means we can address the values in each field. Only make the rule less and less restrictive by requiring it to match all conditions we add.

header: Hack nomore
Fix false-positive on Block Extensions Transport Rule - Attached email Subject line ending with .com
idea_text:
We have noticed a bug in the case where an email subject ends in .com (eg. This is a ), and a user attaches that email (as an attachment on a new message). If there is a Transport Rule set up to block emails by file extension and it includes the .com extension - it will block the email based on the attachment even though .com is not the file extension (it's actually .msg).To recreate the problem in Office 365:Using Outlook or OWA:
1. Send yourself an email with the subject line "this is a "
2. Open a new email message and drag/drop the first email as an attachment onto the new email message.
3. Try to send the message, if you have a Transport Rule enabled which blocks the .com file extension, it will block this email attachment even though it's a .msg file, not a .comThis is the case for any file type specified, if you type the subject of the email to be "This is a ", it will block that as well if the .bat file extension is in the Transport rule, even though it's a .msg file.The only way to get it to work is to use OWA, and save the email to your PC first, then use the Add Attachment option on the new message window - then it will show as a .msg file properly and the email will go through. This same procedure does not work in Outlook, nor does dragging/dropping the email from Outlook or OWA.Hope this makes sense - it's a bug in my opinion.

header: Correct/Fix the SPF interpretation in Message Headers
idea_text:
In a recent email attempting Phish one of our staff and pretending to come from the CEO I discovered an issue with our SPAM filtering.Someone had put our domain in the allowed domain list.
The from address was our domain.
The reply address was a different domain.
The Source IP was not in the SPF record.But becuase the domain was in the allowed list, the header indicates an SPF pass. The header also contains the Forefront SKA analysis indicating where the problem reall is.In my opinion, the SPF pass is a fail on the message processing. Regardles of the SPAM settings, the SPF pass fail must be based only on the actual SPF record. So the header should have read SPF fail. That would have been a clear indication that something else was letting the message in.No SPAM filtering setting should change the accepted standard of how SPF pass/fail is determined.Sincerly
Ivo Duarte

header: Remove Original Email attachment from NDR/Auto response Email
idea_text:
Hi Team,I observed Auto-Response/NDR emails, containing attachments of the original inbound email.When an inbound mail containing PII information as attachment is sent to a O365user (recipient) from an outside sender for any reason, the mail cannot be delivered to the O365 recipient an Auto Generated email containing the original PII attachment is sent back to the original sender from O365.I found there is currently no option in O365 to stop this behaviour or set some control policy but this can be achieved on Exchange On- premise using the parameter –ExternalDsnMaxMessageAttachSize.This parameter is available only in on-premises Exchange and not in Office 365 Exchange online at this moment. The ExternalDsnMaxMessageAttachSize parameter specifies the maximum size of the original message attached to an external DSN message. If the original message exceeds this size, only the headers of the original message are included in the DSN message. The default value is 10 megabytes (MB).This only applies to Exchange On-premise servers also this can be applied on your Hybrid server, but wont help because if all your mailboxes are on Cloud and NDR will be generated by Office 365.So please provide a custom O365 tent functionality for O365 admin center where we can set policy to remove original Email Attached from NDR/Autor Response for External Domain users.Regards,
Adnan Shaikh

header: Dangerous behaviour of SPAM Whitelist
idea_text:
If there are multiple senders in smtp-header, the spam whitelist is checking each of this senders, and if one is included, then the message is whitelisted. Sounds good.I have some pishing eMails received, that are whitelisted, because the faked Sender is in my whitelist.MAIL FROM: <>
From: Display Name <> <>
(no sender field)so, if i have <> in my whitelist, the mail would not be checked as spam. The mail however is sent from >. It would be displayed as 
Display Name <> in Outlook.The SMTP Header "From:" is not RFC compliant. there is missing a comma and a Sender field.
To improve the spam recognition, I would suggest to check the spam whitelist only if the Sender field is rfc compliant..
The Methode above is used to Bypass spf dedection, and this is usually not really required for eMails that I want to see in my Inbox :-)

header: Faltan opciones para la realización de búsquedas por contenido
idea_text:
Desde hace varias semanas hemos venido recibiendo en varios buzones de correo mensajes que incluyen un archivo adjunto de tipo "IMG" (imágenes de disco) el cual a su vez contiene archivos ejecutables. Cuando el usuario abre el archivo adjunto, Windows 10 monta la imagen (crea una unidad de disco en el equipo) y muestra el contenido, el cual al ser abierto infecta el equipo y da inicio a una serie de tareas típicas en casos de malware.
Días después del inicio de estos mensajes entrantes, encontramos que a través de una de las cuentas receptoras se estaban enviando masivamente mensajes del mismo tipo, sin conocimiento del usuario.Hemos intentado realizar una búsqueda en todos los buzones de correo para ubicar si hay más cuentas comprometidas o que hayan recibido archivos adjuntos similares, pero dentro de las opciones de búsqueda no encontramos la forma de referirnos al tipo de archivo adjunto, solo a campos como el asunto, remitente, destinatarios, etc. Al no tener esta opción nos veríamos en la obligación de entrar a cada una de las cuentas a realizar búsquedas similares todos los días, lo que no es factible.

header: Journal unencrypted messages in original format when JournalReportDecryptionEnabled is set to true
idea_text:
Currently when JournalReportDecryptionEnabled is set to true, the archive mailbox gets an unencrypted message with a winmail.dat attachment.  The winmail.dat attachment contains the original unencrypted message.
Instead, it would be much more desirable to simply journal the original message in unencrypted format.
For FINRA (and possibly other agencies) regulated organizations, this is required so that the journaling provider is able to properly index and search journaled messages.
This is causing us to have to use a 3rd party product for message encryption and we'd love to be able to keep that all on Office 365 instead.

header: Retention policies (with records marker) should be manageable by admins
idea_text:
I understand the purpose of records markers in retention policies is to protect official company records. There is, however, a sizeable gap in the functionality to be able to administer such labels even before they are published for use. i.e., even an unpublished (and therefore completely unused) retention label with a company record marker cannot be edited or deleted in any way. Guidance on  does NOT alert anyone to this fact as it notes "WHEN AN ITEM IS LABELLED AS A RECORD, four things happen: 1. The item can't be permanently deleted; 2. The item can't be edited; 3. The label can't be changed; 4. The label can't be removed." 
Actually, the situation is IF A LABEL IS CREATED (AND EVEN NOT PUBLISHED) WHICH APPLIES A RECORD MARKER those four things happen. This is going to quickly result in companies having a plethora of useless and unused retention labels cluttering up their admin consoles and worst still (if published) confusion for their users. 
I suggest that Powershell functionality should be introduced to allow admins to manage retention labels which have record markers.

header: Update DLP rules to close Document Versioning loophole
idea_text:
A file that passes the DLP rules can still contain visible Sensitive information in a previous version of the file. This directly bypasses the intended behaviour of the whole DLP system (to restrict access to sensitive information). One of the primary ways to unlock a DLP locked file is to update the file to remove the sensitive information. By doing so the DLP flag will be removed and file access by other users restored. Currently, this actually exposes the sensitive information contained in the file because these other users can easily view the sensitive information via the version history of the file.This looks to be an oversight in the intended behaviour of the system. The preferable expected behaviour should be that a document is flagged by the DLP system until all versions of the file are clean from sensitive information.Repro Steps
1.	Ensure a DLP policy has been created in the tenant (for example against credit card information), with the behaviour to lock down access to Everyone.
2.	Upload a file that contains credit card information.
3.	Share the file with some users and confirm their access to the file.
4.	Wait for the DLP rules to flag the file. Confirm that access by shared users has been revoked.
5.	Edit the file in question by removing all credit card information.
6.	Wait for the DLP rules to unflag the file. Confirm that access by shared users as been restored.
7.	Using one of the shared users, browse to the file and open the version history for the file.
8.	Open the previous version of the file and confirm that the credit card information is now visible by a person who should not be able to view this information.

header: Disable/Gray out the de-duplication checkbox for bulk/combined eDiscovery exports
idea_text:
In the eDiscovery portal of the Security & Compliance Center, we create several Searches in a single case, when we select all search tasks to bulk export to one PST file, we will notice a checkbox to let us enable or disable de-duplication. However, for bulk export, de-duplication is enabled by default per product design, the checkbox does not make any difference. Can we gray out/disable the checkbox for bulk export to avoid confusion?Design:
• When you export the results of multiple searches, the search queries from all the searches are combined by using OR operators, and then the combined search is started. The estimated results of the combined search are displayed in the details pane of the selected export job. The search results are then transferred to the Azure storage area in the Microsoft cloud. The status of the transfer is also displayed in the details pane. As previously stated, after all the search results have been transferred, you can download them to your local computer.
• If the same email item or document from the same content location is returned by more than one of the searches that you export, only one copy of the item will be exported.

header: Copies of encrypted messages should not be saved unencrypted in "sent" mail folder
idea_text: By default, outgoing encrypted messages are saved automatically in the Sent folder. However, they are not encrypted in the Sent folder.  Users have to manually delete them or write a rule to auto delete them (minimum time frame for this rule to run is one day).  This leaves sensitive data vulnerable in unencrypted state should the account be breached.  Further, web only (kiosk) accounts don't even have the option to not save sent messages.  The encrypted messages should be saved in encrypted format no matter what folder they are in.

comments.text:
Which encryption scheme would this be?Sent mails aren't usually processed through the server, they're just stored. For server-side encryption to do this, you'd need to replace "save to 'sent' folder" by "BCC to $self, rule-based move incoming messages sent by $self to 'sent' folder".A message to several recipients may be delivered encrypted to some of them and clear to some.
Also if it's OME or OMEv2 and the server allows anyone to request a login link with one-time codes if they have access to the mailbox (like it now seems to do), messages encrypted by that system are also compromised if the account is breached. So, the behavior needs to be configurable. (It also tends to work right already if using an external encryption solution.)

header: Mailbox block delivery to client program
idea_text:
According to the new data protection law in Spain and Europe, users have the right to digital disconnection of the company during the time they are outside the company and / or during the days of leave or vacation. If they request it individually, I should be able to prevent them from receiving emails on their mobile phones and laptops (if requested), during those moments. To comply with the law.
How can I configure this in the Outlook panel. Office365.com for my company and my Exchange users?The answer is:
To disconnect the exchange service, you can execute the following powershell command:
Set-CASMailbox -identity ******@domain.com -ewsenabled: $ false -universaloutlookenabled: $ false -mapienabled: $ false -imapenabled: $ false -popenabled: $ false -owaenabled: $ false
Also, when you want to enable the service exchange, you can execute the following command:
Set-CASMailbox -identity ******@domain.com -ewsenabled: $ true -universaloutlookenabled: $ true -mapienabled: $ true -imapenabled: $ true -popenabled: $ true -owaenabled: $ trueThe PowerShell command that we have shared with you can be used to disable and enable services when you want to do so, but during this time users who will send emails to that particular email address will receive refunds.
My company has dismissed this type of actions as being counterproductive for the company. I can not give that bad image to customers (Reject emails) ... .. 
Ideally, the mails should enter the mailbox and block the delivery to mail client programs such as Outlook (Between dates and between scheduled times). If this could be done from the server if I would like to know how to do it ...

header: SharePoint to record whenever a user visits a folder
idea_text: I would like SharePoint to record whenever a user visits a folder, and make that record available through an audit report.If a user navigates into a folder, or views the folder from a SharePoint page (which may have many widgets), then this should be recorded. The reason is that the user has seen the contents of the folder, along with the data of any columns in the folder view. Filenames, subfolder names, and values in columns shown in page views can have sensitive/protected information. As a result, actions that expose them need to be auditable.From a security & auditing point of view, it seems critical to me that these actions be logged. Access to any and all sensitive/protected information needs to be auditable so that organizations can ensure the safety of their data, and prove to stakeholders and regulators that they are properly protecting their data.A support person suggested I post this request here. He said "After looking into this deeper this looks accurate. Simply clicking on a folder is not a recorded event". From a product design perspective, tools should let admins make the decision on what is recorded. If there are performance degradations from excessive recording, then make that known so the admin can make an informed decision. But ultimately, the admin can weight the pros & cons, and make the decision right for his organization.A general comment: We moved from SharePoint On-Premises to O365. The On-Premises auditing reports (generated from .../_layouts/15/Reporting.aspx?Category=Auditing ) were sufficient. However, when we moved to O365 we learned that Microsoft has purposely reduced the amount of events that are viewable from these reports. Therefore, I needed to request my SharePoint admin to generate a report from the back-end that sends a daily CSV to me. This report has more events, but comes in a less digestable JSON format. (See:  ). That adds more work for the customer, because we now need to create a new process to make the audit data presentable in our business user reports/dashboards. Furthermore, it's not clear why the .../_layouts/15/Reporting.aspx?Category=Auditing front-end method not have the same options as the back-end reporting method.Thank you.

header: Improve EOP/ATP antiphishing capabilities by comparing smtp.from and Header From
idea_text:
Hello,We would like to report several advanced phishing e-mails that are evading proper antiphishing EOP/ATP measures (we have opened a support ticket in parallel and were directed to O365 UserVoice).These phishing e-mails bear the following attributes:- The smtp.from is coming from a bogus/random IP and associated domain name, resulting in spf=none verdict
- The Header From is spoofing the corporate target e-mail domains and users
- The To: are the same accounts and corporate domain as the spoofed Header From.The EOP/ATP antiphishing engines are not able to detect that these e-mail samples are phishing (and not spam).We would like to ask that the antiphishing engines/detection logic is improved to perform "integrity" checks between smtp.from and header From.
When detecting a Header From domain that is identical to the Header To: and completely different from the smtp.from (with or without SPF pass for this part), it should severely raise the risk score, and end up being categorised as Phishing.This should not even necessarily need SPF, DKIM or DMARC valid verdicts fully configured on the corporate recipient domain side , as these can and should complement the detection logic in any case.Thank youKind regards

header: Implement A Proper Quarantine Mailbox for Advanced Threat Protection's Safe Attachments
idea_text: We're seeing tons of mail get caught by the Safe Attachments feature in ATP and the experience is horrible.  The only way to monitor blocked attachments right now is to hope that the user notifies you that their email is missing an attachment or utilize the "feature" that allows you to copy all blocked attachments to another mailbox.  Usually I check that and it turns out to be a false positive, but guess what, I can't forward it on to my user because it'll block it again.  Recipient-based filtering is a terrible option and the whitelisting capabilities are another sore spot as addressed by another bit of feedback here -- Please vote for both of these to be resolved.

comments.text:
You could exclude mail sent from the quarantine mailbox from Safe Attachment filtering using a ETR.The ETR would be:1. Condition=from quarantine mailbox
2. Action = Set the message header to this value. Enter in this header X-MS-Exchange-Organization-SkipSafeAttachmentProcessing and set the value to 1That will cause Safe Attachments to skip.
ATP should have the option to redirect to the centralized quarantine.  We've put in the Band-Aid similar to Taylor.
In our case, we have blocked the messages and redirect all messages to a Shared Mailbox.  We periodically check this "quarantine" mailbox.

header: Fix Supervision add-in (Supervisory Review v2) for Outlook desktop

1) A potentially insecure business process so they can fix it.

header: The ability to use regex for incident respose
idea_text: Us InfoSec responders need the ability to search and escape special characters so we can use the security portal to formulate the correct query to get the results we need so that we can purge the malicious emails.For example company is used in the footer of every company email but the phish uses (companyx). Anyone who is going to do searches that are more sophisticated than the web GUI interface allows should be able to grasp regex syntax.  Or search for an appropriate regex query that has already been posted to the web.Ironically, I have found that the loose "natural language" KQL/FQL syntax are often too vague to get accurate results.

header: Restrict permissions of app-only based Graph API applications to individual SharePoint Online resources
idea_text:
Large organization start leveraging the Graph API to provide integrations between their third party applications and Office 365. When developing daemon based applications that usually require app-only permissions, we are facing a compliance and permission issue for such types of applications.If we take SharePoint Online as an example. If a business unit wants to develop daemon tool between their system and a subset of SharePoint Online sites, this cannot be accomplished without granting them access to all SharePoint assets of the organization. 
Let us assume I am going to build a daemon tool that is allowed to write to SharePoint Online, I am usually getting all or nothing from a permissions point of view. In theory, I could start writing in any SharePoint Online site collection without being limited at all. This might work well for all types of applications that are governed by a centrally located IT. On the other hand, it makes impossible to delegate these types of application developements to different business units in the company.Today, the only ways I see to circumvent this problem is by following on of these approaches:
- Fallback to the "classic" SharePoint development model (add-in development) - We are not only not using the Graph API but we have some other issues like the lack of integration with modern security systems such as conditional access.
- Create a cloud only identity and an app having delegated permisions. Grant the access to the specific cloud identity on the desired SharePoint sites - Federated identities do not work in this approach even if these are preferred. You have an added complexity with the need of managing a cloud identity. This is not desired in some enterprises.It would be nice to have the possibility to have a modality to configure app-only permissions which should consider the permissions on the target system such as SharePoint Online. On these target systems you could then start granting permissions to the Application identity to grant proper capabilities.

header: Prevent users from bypassing in-place hold for OneDrive for Business
idea_text:
In Place Holds in SharePoint Online use the search function to identify items that are on hold. Users have the possibility to disable search for their OneDrive for Business: 
Select Site Settings -> Site Libraries and Lists, then select the Documents Library, select Advanced Settings, set Allow items from this document library to appear in search results = NoTesting shows that disabling search bypasses litigation hold allowing users to delete items without preservation.Users should not be able to bypass in-place holds. A possible solution would be to prevent users from disabling search when their OneDrive is placed on hold. Ideally in-place hold would provide a more robust mechanism to ensure deleted / modified items are preserved that doesn't rely on search.

header: Add a "Trust this Device" option to reduce frequency of multi-factor prompt
idea_text: Most multi-factor/ 2-factor authentication schemes allow the user to check a box when they login using the second factor of authentication to say "Trust this Device", meaning "Don't ask for the second-factor code again on this device (optionally: for X days)". [Google, LastPass, Yahoo, ...]Microsoft Office 365 does not have this, which makes good login security unnecessarily burdensome, as the user must have their second factor authentication device with them at all times and use it every time they login.Some users will refuse to use it at all, given the extra burden. Others will use it but be inconvenienced almost every single time they login.The main security purpose of 2-factor authentication is to make theft of simply credentials (1-factor, username+password) much less useful to the attacker. So, for most use cases (logging in on the same office computer, logging in on the same home PC) for security purposes it is not necessary to require the second factor every time the user logs in.Office 365 Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA, "Additional Security Verification") should have an option at each login where the 2-factor prompt is presented, to tick a box saying "Trust this Computer" (optionally, or administrator-configurably, "for X days"), to place a cookie on the device to remove the need to use the second factor when logging in on that device (for some period of time).

header: Add ability to deny EWS and MAPI clients using Basic Authentication, with Client Access Rules for Exchange Online
idea_text:
Currently, MFA for Azure AD / O365 is useless regarding protection of mailboxes in Exchange Online, as EWS and MAPI clients can still connect to mailboxes using Basic Authentication, even with Conditional Access rules in place to require MFA, and there's no way of denying this server-side on EXO.The newly-released Client Access Rules feature promises this functionality in its documentation (see  and , but unfortunately the functionality is crippled. You can only make rules in the following combinations (info from EXO Engineering team):OutlookWebApp:  BasicAuthentication, AdfsAuthentication
ExchangeAdminCenter:  BasicAuthentication, AdfsAuthentication
RemotePowerShell:  BasicAuthentication, NonBasicAuthentication
ExchangeActiveSync:  BasicAuthentication, OAuthAuthentication, CertificateBasedAuthentication
IMAP4/POP3/OfflineAddressBook/PowerShellWebServices/ExchangeWebServices/REST: noneNote there is no mention of OutlookAnywhere (MAPI) in the above list, but from my own testing, it's impossible to create rules around that protocol. EWS is explicitly mentioned as not possible to restrict auth type for.IMAP and POP are also bypasses for MFA, but it's easier to turn those off, but many things are dependent on EWS (including Outlook mobile apps), and Outlook (desktop) is of course dependent on MAPI (OutlookAnywhere). It would be useful to control REST too, as I understand some mobile apps will use that.Yes, you can use CAR's to allow only certain IP's and users to connect with certain protocols, insist everyone VPN's in before connecting, and try to force compliance Outlook client-side, using GPO's to turn on ADAL and then lock down the registry, but this doesn't stop a phisher bypassing MFA for one of your users from whom they've phished username and password, and getting full access to their mailbox.This is a pretty big security hole for us, and I'm surprised there isn't more noise about it across the internet. I just get blank or stock responses from support and escalation engineers on this, so I'm hoping this post helps.

reaction.note: Thanks for taking the time to provide this feedback. We’ve updated the TechNet documentation () to clear up confusion around which authentication type and protocol combinations are supported in CARs. Expanding support for more combinations could prevent bad actors with valid credentials from accessing mailbox content, but it wouldn’t help with scenarios like password spray attacks or malicious lockout attempts because CARs are evaluated post-authentication. There’s work underway on a solution that covers a broader array of basic authentication scenarios – we’ll share more details as soon as possible. In the interim, this blogpost () outlines the recommended approach for forcing multi-factor authentication when using  and .

header: Reduce unnecessary nested includes in your SPF record, to improve DNS efficiency
idea_text: If you run a service which might be responsible for sending mails on behalf of a customer, and consequently have an SPF record they need to "include:" in their own, I think that you should probably review it and see if you have an excessive number of DNS lookups in your SPF record.The problem is that if a customer of more than one of these mail service providers, and they have multiple include elements in their SPF record, it’s all too easy to breach the 10 DNS lookup limit, which could lead to random email loss (recipient MTAs giving up on DNS lookups and bouncing/rejecting legitimate emails).For instance, include:spf.protection.outlook.com resolves to the following: -"v=spf1 ip4:207.46.101.128/26 ip4:207.46.100.0/24 ip4:207.46.163.0/24 ip4:65.55.169.0/24 ip4:157.55.133.0/25 ip4:157.56.110.0/23 ip4:157.55.234.0/24 ip4:213.199.154.0/24 ip4:213.199.180.0/24 include:spfa.protection.outlook.com -all"which leads to include:spfa.protection.outlook.com: -"v=spf1 ip4:157.56.120.0/25 ip4:157.56.116.0/25 ip4:157.56.112.0/24 ip4:207.46.51.64/26 ip4:157.55.158.0/23 ip4:157.56.87.192/26 ip4:64.4.22.64/26 ip4:40.92.0.0/14 ip4:134.170.140.0/24 include:spfb.protection.outlook.com -all"which in turn, leads to include:spfb.protection.outlook.com: -"v=spf1 ip6:2a01:111:f400::/48 ip4:23.103.128.0/19 ip4:23.103.198.0/23 ip4:65.55.88.0/24 ip4:104.47.0.0/17 ip4:23.103.200.0/21 ip4:23.103.208.0/21 ip4:23.103.191.0/24 ip4:216.32.180.0/23 ip4:40.107.0.0/16 ip4:94.245.120.64/26 -all"Now, most of the SPF include records I’ve seen, are perfectly able to live in a single, long DNS record - longer than 255 characters - simply by separating them with '" " ' (an end quote, a space, a start quote and a space) - these breaks are not seen in the final record - See the Internet Systems Consortium Knowledge Base article, Can I have a TXT or SPF record longer than 255 characters? ()You can easily check the number of DNS lookups an SPF record requires, using dmarcian - SPF Surveyor (.In your case, there are too many IPs to contain them all in a single DNS Resource Record (and keep it within the 512 byte DNS UDP response size limit), but you can flatten/minimise the records like so (the first record is 2x <255 character sections & if/when the 2nd record grows >255 characters, that can be similarly split): -spf.protection.outlook.com IN TXT "v=spf1 ip4:207.46.101.128/26 ip4:207.46.100.0/24 ip4:207.46.163.0/24 ip4:65.55.169.0/24 ip4:157.55.133.0/25 ip4:157.56.110.0/23 ip4:157.55.234.0/24 ip4:213.199.154.0/24 ip4:213.199.180.0/24 ip4:157.56.120.0/25" " ip4:157.56.116.0/25 ip4:157.56.112.0/24 ip4:207.46.51.64/26 ip4:157.55.158.0/23 ip4:157.56.87.192/26 ip4:64.4.22.64/26 ip4:40.92.0.0/14 ip4:134.170.140.0/24 ip4:23.103.128.0/19 ip4:23.103.198.0/23 ip4:65.55.88.0/24 include:spfa.protection.outlook.com -all"spfa.protection.outlook.com IN TXT "v=spf1 ip4:104.47.0.0/17 ip4:23.103.200.0/21 ip4:23.103.208.0/21 ip4:23.103.191.0/24 ip4:216.32.180.0/23 ip4:40.107.0.0/16 ip4:94.245.120.64/26 ip6:2a01:111:f400::/48 -all"I know I am but a small fish, in Microsoft’s big pond, but I firmly believe that this small improvement in efficiency (1 fewer DNS lookup), as well as benefiting my company (as our SPF record is overcrowded), it should have a positive effect on the number of DNS queries Microsoft’s DNS service will have to perform (~1/3 fewer).
